bestBHT.bht: In this account, there is a large herd of swine on a mountain where the evil spirits requested Jesus's permission to enter them. It is interesting to note that the term herd is seen only in the New Testament and parallels the works of Homer. However, the presence of the spirits in the swine did not bring them any ease, as they soon went on to destroy the entire herd. This episode demonstrates Jesus's authority over evil spirits and highlights their inevitable destruction, regardless of their dwelling place.

Archibald T. Robertson: Word herd (αγελη) old as Homer, but in N.T. only here and parallels (Mark 5:11; Matthew 8:30).
Luke shows his fondness for adjective ικανος here again (see verse Luke 8:27) where Mark has μεγαλη and Matthew πολλων.
John Gill: And there was there an herd of many swine."
And they besought him that he would suffer them to enter into them; which they could not do, without his leave: and he suffered them.
John Wesley: To enter into the swine — Not that they were any easier in the swine than out of them.
Had it been so, they would not so soon have dislodged themselves, by destroying the herd.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, there is a herd of many swine present, illustrating Luke's fondness for the adjective ικανος which describes a large number. The word herd is a rare term used only in the New Testament and is reminiscent of Homer's writings. The swine are feeding on a mountain, and the evil spirits possessing the man beseeched Jesus to allow them to enter the swine. However, it is noted that entering the swine did not provide any relief for the spirits, as they ultimately destroyed the entire herd. This passage highlights the power of Jesus over evil spirits and shows that their ultimate destruction was inevitable, regardless of their presence in the swine.

In this account, a large herd of swine is being fed on a mountain where evil spirits beseeched Jesus to enter them. Interestingly, this term herd is only used in the New Testament and is reminiscent of Homer's works. The presence of the spirits in the swine did not alleviate their distress, as they proceeded to destroy the entire herd. It serves as a powerful demonstration of Jesus's authority over evil spirits and emphasizes that their destruction was inevitable regardless of their dwelling place.
